justification: The article describes a paradigm in which “a participant chooses between two (or more) potential partners for an economic interaction, whether that be a trust game…”, indicating that choices made within the Trust Game are used to measure partner-choice behavior.
In the same discussion the authors note that participants may choose between partners “in a prisoner’s dilemma”, showing that Prisoner’s Dilemma choices serve as a measure of partner choice.
The representative paradigm list also includes “a dictator game”, signalling that whom participants pick for a Dictator Game interaction operationalises the construct of partner choice.

The review refers to decisions made “in group contexts (e.g. a public goods game)” where individuals “exclude those who contribute the least”, evidencing use of Public Goods Game partner inclusion or exclusion to measure partner choice.

measured_by: Amount donated in the Dictator Game
justification: Under the heading ‘We choose partners who have been generous and fair’, the authors state that “we appear to choose partners who donate to others…or give to others in a dictator game”, identifying Dictator Game donations as the behavioural measure of generosity/fairness.

measured_by: Contribution levels in the Public Goods Game
justification: The paper notes, “We prefer those who play cooperatively or contribute more, both in group contexts (e.g. a public goods game)”, indicating that contribution amounts within the Public Goods Game operationalise a person’s cooperative disposition.
